title: Why do I have to learn philosophy of science in school? - Quora

response.answer_text: I wasn’t aware you HAVE to learn Philosophy of Science in school. Nonetheless, the more you learn of this subject, the better… A well-informed citizen knows: That unlike some fields, modern science largely rejects authority as an ultimate decider of questions. There are authorities, of course, but their authority is only temporary and can be overruled by evidence at any time.Modern science relies on evaluation of evidence and is self-correcting. This is one of the aspects of science that make it so often right, or at least useful.Science, especially “hard science,” is strongly predictive. You can use Newtonian physics, for example, to predict the action of tides, and these results can be easily verfied.Scientific theories that produce no testifiable or verifiable predictions are questionable, until such a time as they can make predictions.At the same time, Philosophy of Science does posit a kind of “faith,” in that it assumes the universe is predictable, regular, and subject to causation. It is useful to understand why the philosopher David Hume raised questions about these assumptions.The historical roles of Science v. Politics and Science v. Religion are rich areas of understanding… in general, both religion and politics have usually done better to leave science alone, to let it objectively evaluate evidence — which is not something people in the religion or political fields are always good at. Most of these ideas, by the way, could be picked up by closely watching Carl Sagan’s version of “Cosmos,” along with the more recent version by Neil deGrasse Tyson. But if you don’t get this from popular science books (which you could read on your own) or Sagan’s program, you ought to be getting it in school. And if you do understand Philosophy of Science, you should also understand the role of peer-reviewed articles, which in turn should help you understand that Climate Change is a real thing.

I’d be quite surprised if you have to learn it in school, assuming that school here refers to high school, but there are quite a few good reasons to promote learning at least the basics of philosophy of science: It teaches that science is a process rather than just a body of knowledge. Science isn’t just about all the good answers that we came up with, but also the failures.It teaches that this process is influenced by paradigms (Kuhn), funding, personal convictions and expectations, etc. In other words: it doesn’t move unidirectionally towards the ‘truth’ (which is a troublesome notion itself)It teaches how difficult it is to define what science is exactly and how to distinguish it from pseudo-science (demarcation criterium)It teaches how to evaluate the quality of scientific researchIn other words: if it succeeds in conveying the idea that science is a flawed but useful process influenced by many factors that is very hard to define, that class has been successful. This can avoid things like: “It’s not true. It’s just a theory!”“Newton was wrong!”“Chocolate is healthy! No, chocolate in unhealthy!”It allows students to put science into context while at the same time distinguishing it from pseudoscience, which is something very few people are capable of, apparently.
